0ad94470-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.name: Block 1
0ad94470-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.content: "-- Create the schema\nCREATE SCHEMA IF NOT EXISTS jdbc"

0ad94470-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.name: Block
0ad94470-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.content:
"-- Create the JDBC data source that points to the 'nyct2010' Google Spreadsheet
CREATE OR REPLACE DATA SOURCE jdbc.gsheets
LOCATION = 'jdbc:cdata:googlesheets:OAuthVerifier=PASTE YOUR AUTH CODE HERE;InitiateOAuth=REFRESH;Spreadsheet=nyct2010'
"

0ad94470-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.name: Block
0ad94470-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.content:
"CREATE OR REPLACE DATA SOURCE jdbc.gsheets_test
LOCATION = 'jdbc:cdata:googlesheets:OAuthVerifier=4/1AdQt8qgP5GWnSUaI3y7TdmDZ1fAipMuYyyYbofvl_Yz0xPOX-Th-4KzIFJ4;InitiateOAuth=REFRESH;Spreadsheet=test123';

LOAD DATA INTO jdbc.test123
FROM REMOTE QUERY 'SELECT * FROM test123_Sheet1'
WITH OPTIONS (
    DATA SOURCE = 'jdbc.gsheets_test',
    ON ERROR = SKIP
)"

0ad94470-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.name: Block
0ad94470-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.content:
"-- Create the table
CREATE OR REPLACE MATERIALIZED EXTERNAL TABLE jdbc.nyct2010
(
    "id" INTEGER,
    "gid" INTEGER (primary_key) NOT NULL,
    "geom" GEOMETRY,
    "CTLabel" VARCHAR (16),
    "BoroCode" VARCHAR (16),
    "BoroName" VARCHAR (16),
    "CT2010" VARCHAR (16),
    "BoroCT2010" VARCHAR (16),
    "CDEligibil" VARCHAR (16),
    "NTACode" VARCHAR (16),
    "NTAName" VARCHAR (64),
    "PUMA" VARCHAR (16),
    "Shape_Leng" DOUBLE,
    "Shape_Area" DOUBLE
);"

0ad94470-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.name: Block
0ad94470-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.content:
"LOAD DATA INTO jdbc.nyct2010
FROM REMOTE QUERY 'SELECT * FROM nyct2010_Sheet1'
WITH OPTIONS 
(
    DATA SOURCE = 'jdbc.gsheets',
    ON ERROR = SKIP
)"

0ad94470-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.name: Block
0ad94470-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"bold":true,"text":"WHAT IS A SCHEMA?"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Schemas are logical containers for most database objects (tables, views, indexes, etc.), grouped together under a common name. In order to place an object in a schema, the schema must be created first—schemas will not be automatically created when specified in CREATE TABLE or similar calls."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"bold":true,"text":"CREATE A NEW SCHEMA"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We will use the 'jdbc' schema to organize the tables and data objects for this example."}]}]

0ad94470-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.name: Block
0ad94470-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"CREATE THE DATA SOURCE","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Paste the authorization code that you generated (see prerequisites) earlier as the value for OAuthVerifier in the query below (LOCATION parameter)."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"✎ "},{"text":"Note","bold":true},{"text":": The CDATA connector is specified separately for each spreadsheet. "}]}]

0ad94470-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.name: Block
0ad94470-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.content:
"CREATE MATERIALIZED EXTERNAL TABLE "jdbc"."nyct2010"
(
    "id" INTEGER NOT NULL,
    "gid" INTEGER (primary_key) NOT NULL,
    "geom" GEOMETRY,
    "CTLabel" VARCHAR (16),
    "BoroCode" VARCHAR (16),
    "BoroName" VARCHAR (16),
    "CT2010" VARCHAR (16),
    "BoroCT2010" VARCHAR (16),
    "CDEligibil" VARCHAR (16),
    "NTACode" VARCHAR (16),
    "NTAName" VARCHAR (64),
    "PUMA" VARCHAR (16),
    "Shape_Leng" DOUBLE,
    "Shape_Area" DOUBLE
);
"

0ad94470-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.name: Block
0ad94470-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"CREATE THE TABLE","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"While Kinetica has a good type inferencing system, it is always a best practice to define the table schema before loading data into it. "}]}]

0ad94470-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.name: Block
0ad94470-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.content:
"LOAD INTO jdbc.nyct2010
FROM REMOTE QUERY 'SELECT * FROM nyct2010_Sheet1'
WITH OPTIONS 
(
    DATA SOURCE = 'jdbc.gsheets',
    ON ERROR = SKIP 
)"

0ad94470-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.name: Block
0ad94470-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"LOAD THE DATA","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Data is loaded by issuing a query to the remote data source. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"✎ Note: ","bold":true},{"text":" The googlesheets API uses the syntax 'spreadsheet_sheetName' to identify the sheet from which to load the data."}]}]

0b6d6e20-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.name: Block
0b6d6e20-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"WHAT IS JDBC?","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Java Database Connectivity (JDBC) is a standardized API for interacting with databases using Java programs. Kinetica offers a data source that can be used to connect to other databases and applications using a JDBC driver. We can then issue remote queries to this data source to load and export data to and from Kinetica into this data source."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"CDATA","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Kinetica has also partnered with CData, a data connectivity platform that offers JDBC drivers for hundreds of different databases and applications."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"bold":true,"text":"TWO ROUTES"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"There are two ways to register a JDBC data source. You can either Bring Your Own Driver (BYOD), or you can use a driver provided by CData."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"bold":true,"text":"THIS DEMO"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In this demo, we explore both the BYOD and CData routes. First, we will use a CData driver to load data from Google Sheets into Kinetica, and then we will bring our own JDBC driver to connect to a Postgres database."}]}]

0b6d6e20-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.name: Block
0b6d6e20-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"❗️NOTE: THIS ONLY WORKS ON DEVELOPER EDITION. ","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This workbook showcases certain admin features that will only work in the Developer's Edition and not on the Kinetica Cloud."}]}]

0b82a3d0-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.name: Block 1
0b82a3d0-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.content:
"CREATE OR REPLACE DATA SOURCE jdbc.postgres_ds
LOCATION = 'jdbc:postgresql://172.17.0.3:5432/dellstore'
USER = 'postgres'
PASSWORD = 'postgres'
WITH OPTIONS
(
  JDBC_DRIVER_JAR_PATH = 'kifs://drivers/postgresql-42.7.1.jar',
  JDBC_DRIVER_CLASS_NAME = 'org.postgresql.Driver'
)"

0b82a3d0-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.name: Block
0b82a3d0-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"WHAR IS POSTGRES DATABASE","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Postgres is a very popular open-source relational database management system. The worksheets shows how to connect to an instance of Postgres using JDBC."}]}]

0b82a3d0-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.name: Block
0b82a3d0-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.content:
"LOAD INTO jdbc.products
FROM REMOTE QUERY 'SELECT * FROM products'
WITH OPTIONS 
(
    DATA SOURCE = 'jdbc.postgres_ds'
)"

0b82a3d0-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.name: Block
0b82a3d0-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"CREATE THE DATA SOURCE","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The credential for accessing the PostgreSQL database (if using the docker version in pre-reqs) is 'postgres'. Make sure the PostgreSQL database is up and running before registering the data source."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"✎ Note","bold":true},{"text":": The data source is registered for 'dellstore'. You can try replacing it with other datasets."}]}]

0b82a3d0-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.name: Block
0b82a3d0-94b0-11ee-8c36-d1af09c7db0b.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"LOAD DATA","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In the query below, we use Kinetica's type inferencing system to directly load the data from PostgreSQL into a table without having created the table in Kinetica first."}]}]

config.html_source:
PRE-REQUISITES

  1. Spreadsheet data: You will need access to a google spreadsheet with tabular data to complete this demo. The following link contains the data that was used for this demo. You can create a copy of this (under your google account) to repeat the same steps as those below.
  2. Authentication: Generate an authorization code for CData. Make sure to copy and save the code.
  3. Enable Procs: Log into Gadmin and change the 'enable procs' setting in the configuration file to true. Restart the database service.

STEPS

  1. Register the data source: We will use the CData JDBC driver to register a google spreadsheet as our data source. You can read more about the CData driver here.
  2. Create the table: Kinetica has a type inferencing system. We can use that to get a first version of the DDL using the ingestion mode 'TYPE INFERENCE' (see options). We can then modify the DDL as we need to create the table in Kinetica.
  3. Load data from the data source: In the case of Google Sheets, each data source points to a spreadsheet. And each sheet inside the spreadsheet contains data that can be loaded into a table. The CData driver uses the spreadsheet_sheetname syntax to identify the sheet that a SQL query will be issued to.

HOW TO GENERATE AUTHENTICATION CODE?

  1. Use the following link to access CData's website.
  2. Click on 'Getting Started' in the pane and then click on 'Establishing a Connection'.
  3. Click on 'Headless Machines' in the right pane and click on the embedded link that says 'Google Sheets OAuth endpoint'.
  4. Sign in with the preferred Google Account, then click 'Allow,' and finally, copy and save the code.

PRE-REQUISITES

  1. Postgres database: Follow the instructions here to install a containerized instance of Postgres with some sample data.
  2. JDBC driver for PostgreSQL: Download the PostgreSQL driver from the following link and load into KiFS
  3. Enable Procs: This should already be turned on if you completed the instructions in the previous worksheet.

STEPS

❗️Note: Ensure that Docker is downloaded and currently running.
  1. Copy the command 'docker run -d --name pg-ds-all aa8y/postgres-dataset:all' and paste it into your terminal.
  2. Return to Docker and verify if the new container 'pg-ds-all' is listed there.
  3. In the Kinetica Workbench, click on 'Files' located on the left pane. Then, click on the '+' sign and select 'Upload New File.'
  4. Name the new file 'drivers' and choose the PostgreSQL driver you recently downloaded to your computer.
  5. To double-check the IP address of the PostgreSQL instance, use the 'ip a' command in Docker Hub and ensure that the IP address is '172.17.0.3/16.' If not, update the IP address in the query below.
  6. To verify the port number, use the 'docker ps' command outside the Docker Hub and ensure that the port number is '5432.' If not, update the port number in the query below.
  7. Run the query below to connect the PostgreSQL database to a datasource called 'postgres_ds.'
For more information about connecting a PostgreSQL database to Kinetica, refer to this video.
